unnormalised: ## Integrating My Sanity: A Calculus Confession
normalised: ## Integrating My Sanity: A Calculus Confession

unnormalised: So, I thought I was pretty smart, you know? IIT JEE cleared with a decent rank, coding skills that would make Bill Gates blush (okay, maybe just mildly impressed). Then I met Integral Calculus. And let me tell you, it's been a journey. A long, winding, constantly-derailing journey where the only constant is my confusion.
normalised: So, I thought I was pretty smart, you know? I-I-T J-E-E cleared with a decent rank, coding skills that would make Bill Gates blush (okay, maybe just mildly impressed). Then I met Integral Calculus. And let me tell you, it's been a journey. A long, winding, constantly-derailing journey where the only constant is my confusion.

unnormalised: Seriously, what's up with all the symbols? It’s like someone threw a bunch of squiggles and letters onto a page and dared me to make sense of it. ∫? ∑? dx? It looks like a secret code designed to filter out the truly intelligent. I mean, give me a break! I can debug a complex algorithm in 3 hrs, but finding the antiderivative of some function with trig identities involved feels like trying to herd cats in a monsoon.
normalised: Seriously, what's up with all the symbols? It's like someone threw a bunch of squiggles and letters onto a page and dared me to make sense of it. integral? summation? d x? It looks like a secret code designed to filter out the truly intelligent. I mean, give me a break! I can debug a complex algorithm in three hours, but finding the antiderivative of some function with trig identities involved feels like trying to herd cats in a monsoon.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the different techniques. U-substitution? Integration by parts? Partial fractions? It's like a mathematical version of "Mission: Impossible." Sometimes, I manage to pull off a successful integration, feeling like Tom Cruise hanging from a helicopter. But most of the time, I crash and burn, ending up with an answer that's off by a factor of 'c' (the ever-elusive constant of integration!). That darn c! It's like the mathematical equivalent of finding your keys – you know they're somewhere, but you just can't find them!

unnormalised: My professor, Dr. Sharma, god bless her soul, tries to explain it with enthusiasm. She uses real-world examples, like calculating the area under a curve to estimate the rainfall in Chennai during the monsoon or determining the volume of a spherical gulab jamun (genius, right?). But even those delicious examples can't always penetrate the fog of my calculus-induced brain freeze. I keep picturing her drawings of the curves on a graph board, wishing my marks would go that high.

unnormalised: I tried everything. Hours of study sessions fueled by chai and samosas, countless YouTube tutorials where some guy with a whiteboard tries to explain it like I'm 5 (maybe I am when it comes to calculus). I even downloaded a fancy app called "Integral Solver 5000," hoping it would magically make me a calculus whiz. Spoiler alert: it didn't. The app gave the answer alright, but I still had no idea how to *arrive* at that answer in those dreaded 2 hrs of the exam.

unnormalised: There was this one time I thought I had nailed it. I spent all night solving a complex integral, convinced I was about to become a calculus god. I wrote my answer in bold, underlined it twice, and felt a surge of confidence that could rival Amitabh Bachchan in a Bollywood movie. I scored 3/10. *3*! Apparently, somewhere along the line, I had committed a cardinal sin of calculus, and the only thing I had integrated was my own sense of self-worth.

unnormalised: So, here I am, still wrestling with Integral Calculus. I haven't given up hope yet, though. I figure, if I can survive the Mumbai local during rush hour, I can survive this. Maybe, just maybe, one day I'll actually understand what I'm doing. Until then, I'll just keep drinking chai, watching YouTube videos, and praying to the math gods for a little bit of mercy.
